{{wikipedia}}
{{also|Appendix:Variations of "us"}}
==English==

===Etymology 1===
From {{etyl|enm}} {{term|us|lang=enm}}, from {{etyl|ang}} {{term|us|Å«s|pos=dative personal pronoun|us|lang=ang}}, from {{proto|Germanic|uns|us|lang=en}}, from {{proto|Indo-European|ne-||nÅ-||n-ge-||n-sme-|us|lang=en}}. Cognate with {{etyl|fry|-}} {{term|us|lang=fry}}, {{term|us|Ãºs|us|lang=fry}}, {{etyl|nds|-}} {{term|us||us|lang=nds}}, {{etyl|nl|-}} {{term|ons||us|lang=nl}}, {{etyl|de|-}} {{term|uns||us|lang=de}}, {{etyl|da|-}} {{term|os||us|lang=da}}, {{etyl|la|-}} {{term|nos|nÅs|we, us|lang=la}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{qualifier|stressed}} {{enPR|Å­s}}, {{IPA|/ÊŒs/}}, {{SAMPA|/Vs/}}
* {{qualifier|unstressed}} {{IPA|/É™s/}}, {{SAMPA|/@s/}}
* {{audio|en-us-us.ogg|Audio (US)}}
*: {{rhymes|ÊŒs}}

====Pronoun====
{{en-pron}}

# {{personal}} [[me]] and at least one other person; the objective case of '''[[we]]'''.
# {{colloquial}} [[me]]
#: ''Give '''us''' a look at your paper.''
#: ''Give '''us''' your fuckin' wallet!''

=====Quotations=====
* '''1611''' â€” [[w:King James Version of the Bible|King James Version of the Bible]], ''[[s:Bible (King James)/Luke|Luke]] 1:1''
*: Forasmuch as many have taken in hand to set forth in order a declaration of those things which are most surely believed among '''us'''...

====Determiner====
{{en-det}}

# The speakers/writers, or the speaker/writer and at least one other person.
#: ''It's not good enough for '''us''' teachers.''

=====See also=====
* [[we]]

===Etymology 2===
Derived from the similarity between the letter [[u]] and the Greek letter [[Âµ]].

====Symbol====
'''us'''

# {{alternative spelling of|Âµs}}

==French==

===Etymology===
{{etyl|fro|fr}} {{term|us|lang=fro}} < {{etyl|la|fr}} {{term|usus|lang=la}}

===Noun===
{{infl|fr|noun|g=m|g2=p}}

# {{plurale tantum|lang=fr}} [[customs]]; [[traditions]]

====Usage notes====
only used in Modern French as ''us et coutumes'' (traditions and customs)

===Anagrams===
* [[su#French|su]]

==Old English==

===Etymology===
From {{proto|Germanic|lang=ang}} from {{proto|Indo-European|nÌ¥s||nes|lang=ang}}. Cognates include Old Frisian {{term|us|Å«s|lang=ofs}} (West Frisian {{term|us|Ãºs|lang=fy}}), Old Saxon {{term|us|Å«s|lang=osx}} (Dutch {{term|ons|lang=nl}}), Old High German {{term|uns|lang=goh}} (German {{term|uns|lang=de}}), Old Norse {{term|oss|lang=non}} (Swedish {{term|oss|lang=sv}}), Gothic {{term|ğŒ¿ğŒ½ğƒ|tr=uns|lang=got|sc=Goth}}.  The Indo-European root is also the source of Latin {{term|nos|lang=la}}.

===Pronunciation===
* {{IPA|/uËs/|lang=ang}}

===Pronoun===
{{infl|ang|pronoun|head=Å«s|personal pronoun}}

# [[us#English|us]]: accusative or dative plural form of [[ic#Old English|iÄ‹]]

----
